bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 4, 1876

div1.p: Reed misses Emilie Lawrence. He is thankful for the time spent with her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 4, 1876
div1.p:
We have
just left “Old Point” & are
now under full head way for
the Monumental City, at which
place I find that I will be
compelled to remain till 10 P.M
to-morrow- It appears that the
cars do not leave in the Mor-
ning, as I had anticipated, so
that I will not reach my
Post till Monday Morning; &
as my leave expires Tuesday,
it is well that I started on
my journey to-day. How I
wish that there was some
more speedy method of
travelling, so that I could go
from Murfreesboro to New
York in 2 or 3 hours- Then
I might remain with my
little love till the last hours
were slipping by & enjoy her
sweet society (society that
I enjoy more than all other
things else) as long as possi-
ble. But I will not com-
plain- for surely I have no
cause for murmuring- That
I was directed by some in-
scrutable power to your
little town; that I was per-
mitted to offer you my hand,
that I now possess your
esteem & am permitted to
spend a few days at your
feet, this makes me more
than grateful- I will not
murmur- When I think
that I might have been
sent far away from you
& debarred by distance from
visiting you, save at long
intervals, I am more than
happy that I have been per-
mitted to see you not once,
but many times- Surely, I
must reckon myself as for-
tunate- Yes, instead of fee-
lings of sadness stealing
o'er me, to-night, I send up
from a thankful heart an
incense to High Heaven-
Should I not do so? Are
you not the the sweetest,
and most precious girl
that ever blessed a man
with her love! Oh! you
darling little Angel! (for if
there ever was an Angel on
earth, you are one, my Sweet,)
is not my heart full to over-
flowing with love for your
dear self! Love so full,
that you, my darling, will
never be able to fathom it.
Oh! that I could, to-night,
fold you in my arms & press
you to a heart which beats
alone for you!

Good night, my Emilie, &
may angels guard thy sweet
sleep-
div1.closer:
Ever, your own
fond & devoted Walter.
